ALLEGATION:
Three staff members at facility may have pinched youth.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred to DCWL and assigned on 03/14/2022.
I interviewed complainant via telephone on 03/14/2022. She reported Youth A‘s
grandmother said that Youth A told her Staff 1, 2, and 3 had pinched him. Youth A
did not have any marks or bruises.
I interviewed Director 1 at the facility on 03/15/2022. Youth A attends the center on
Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday. She reported Youth A is diagnosed with Septo-
optic dysplasia and Autism. He is legal blind; he has behavior issues and when
agitated will throw things and bite. She was informed that Youth A said that Staff 1,
2, and 3 had pinched him last week, so on 03/14/2022 an incident report and a body
chart was completed on Youth A. There were two small bruises below his knees and
2

one on his forearm. Staff follow the developmentally appropriate positive invention
strategies when a youth is having a behavioral episode. Staff use redirecting and
encourage positive behavioral. Staff are prohibited from using any form of physical
discipline. She reported Staff 1 and 2 are present today, but Staff 3 is off this week.
I observed Youth A at the facility on 03/15/2022. Youth A could not be interviewed
due to his limited ability to communicate and answer questions. He was observed to
be playing and engaging with staff. He appeared to be clean, neat, and playful. No
concerns observed. He was asked what he likes about the facility and he replied he
likes me.
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility on 03/15/2022. Staff 1 has been working at the
facility for 8 months as a Child Worker and has completed all training. She works
second shift 3:30 to 9 pm. She denied ever pinching or using any form of physical
discipline with Youth A or any other youth at the facility. She reported talking and
redirecting is the only form of discipline used when a youth is having a behavioral
episode and if that does not work, she would get a supervisor to assist. She denied
witnessing any staff pinch or use any form of physical discipline with the youths.
She reported she enjoys working with the children and would never do anything to
hurt the children. She was visibly very upset about the allegations.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 03/15/2022. Staff 2 has been working at the
facility for four months and has completed all her training. She works afternoon shift,
but has never worked with Youth A. She said Youth A will always ask staff when
they walk in the room, “what is your name”, which is how he knows staffs’ names.
She denied pinching or having any interaction with Youth A. She reported following
the facility’s positive intervention strategies when addressing behavioral issues with
all the youths.
I interviewed Relative 1 via telephone on 03/17/2022. She reported Youth A told her
that he plays a pinching game with the staff. She said Youth A changed his story
later and told her staff pinch him. She did not see any bruises on Youth A, so she
does not believe him. She reported Youth A will sometimes lie and makeup stories.
She expressed no concerns about the staff or the facility. She reported staff do an
excellent job taking care of Youth A.
I interviewed Staff 3 via telephone on 03/31/2022. Staff 3 has been working at the
facility for 6 months as a Child Worker and has completed all training. She denied
pinching Youth A. She reported no physical discipline is used with any of the youths.
She said staff use talking and redirecting when a youth is having a behavioral
episode. She has completed CPI training and uses the positive intervention
strategies when dealing with a youth that is having an episode. She expressed that
all staff follow the positive intervention when dealing with the youths and feels that is
what is so exceptional about the facility.
3

Documents reviewed for the investigation:
 Facility’s Behavioral Management Policy. Staff use the following developmentally
appropriate positive intervention to assist children in developing improved self-
control, self-direction, cooperation, problem solving, self-management, and social
skills:
o Modeling Appropriate Behavioral
o Set Reasonable and Consistent Expectations
o Provide Opportunities for Choice Making
o Ignoring Negative or Attention Seeking Behaviors
o Reinforce Positive Behaviors
o The primary focus of behavioral
o Connect to Children’s Feelings
o Reward Menus
o Time Out
 Youth A’s Behavior Update Report dated 09/23/2021. Youth A exhibits ongoing
aggressive behaviors such as tantrum, biting, pinching, swearing, scratching,
shoving, throwing toys, and swearing/name calling. Staff are to ignore and
redirect Youth A when he displays negative behavior and are to encourage
positive behavioral support.
 Incident Report and body chart dated 03/14/2022 completed by Director 1. That
is consistent with Director’s interview.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4158 Discipline.
(2) An institution shall prohibit all cruel and severe
discipline, including any of the following:
(a) Any type of corporal punishment inflicted in any
manner.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule as there is no supporting
evidence that these allegations occurred. Youth A could not be
interviewed due to his limited cognitive ability. Staff were
interviewed and denied pinching Youth A. Youth A’s relative was
also interviewed they don’t believe that staff pinched him.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the lack of findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the
current license status.
